195
Folk Lore
Manibojou Stories.

  The Ojibway tribes all reverence and hold in high esteem the Demigod Manibojou and like the ancient people of history they are pessessed [sic] of much mythology that is fast melting  and fading from the memory of the "old men" and the young ones never learn it as the old coucil fires are out and such stories are related only in the winter and at night about a council fire.  To tell them at other times would be "bad medicine" and very much displease the Manito (or Manido).  so with the incroachments of civilization disappear the old indian traditions a few are left. however and no doubt more might be gleaned if the council fires could be again lighted. as we have been told that the Ojibway have a great store of such stories. recounting the exploits of Manibojou.

Manibojou
"This Maniboujou is a mythical character half Manito and half man.  His time is spent partly in playing pranks upon the indian.  that is the mean side and the rest in teaching them arts and thinking over things and inventing different things for the benefit of the indian.  He is fond of amusing himself and at such times he does it at the expense of the indians or some of the animals.  His origin is this [?] a Manito came to the earth: then the world was young and fresh. and he saw and loved and married an indian maiden after a long courtship for she was shy of this Manito but finally yielded to his advances.   She did not know that he was a Manito he was so well disguised as a man.   In due time however the squaw gave birth to four goodly sons * and died  "Maniboju" was the eldest.   he was the friend of the human race.  The second was "Chibiabos" who has charge of the dead. and presides over the city of souls  The third was "Wabasso" who as soon as he saw the light fled away to the north, where he was changed into a white rabbit. and in this form is a great spirit.  The fourth or youngest was "Cho-kan-in-pok." or "the Man of Flint," or the firestone.  When Manibojou grew up he made war upon his brother "Chokanipok" because he was as the alleged the cause of his Mother's death.  They fought fierce battles. and when ever they had an encounter the face of nature [?] it as all the fragments of the body of Chokanipok

That this is not an improbable tale see, "Nielman History of the Jews."

196
which Manibijou hewed off were turned into flint and are the fire stones scattered over the face of the earth.  "Chokanipok" was finally destroyed by tearing his entrails out which were by Manibijou immediately turned into [crossed out: stones] [?].  The fire stones Manibijou scattered about so that man kind might have the principle of fire always at hand.

  Manibojou taught men how to make their axes lances. arrow points. garments. and articles of bone and stone. and also to make snares and traps for game.  After he had killed his brother "Chokan-i-pok" he [?] his brother Chibiabos. and they lived. retired and together. planning things for the good of men.  These two Manito [?] were so considered [?] superior to all the other Manito. and then lived in the air. and earth and water became Jealous of them and [?] into a conspiracy against them.  Manibijou warned his brother not to leave his side but one day Chilbiabos went alone on the Great Lake. the surface was frozen.  When he reached the middle the Manito of the water broke the ice and precipitated him to the bottom.  they hid his body.   [?] discovered this and waged deadly war against the Manitos and sent number of them to the abyss.  He put the whole world in fear of him and smearing his face with [?black?]. sat down and lamented his brother for six years.  The Manito held a council and consulted as to how to appease his wrath. the oldest of them agreed to attempt to reconcile him.  A sacred lodge was built near that of Manibijou and a feast was prepared.  They procured the most delicious tobacco and filled a pipe.  Then they formed in order in single file each bearing his sack or pouch formed of the skin of some potent animal. as a Bear. Otter Lynx etc. each filled with precious and curious medicine.  culled from all plants.  These they showed to Manibijou and asked him to Join the feast.  He raised his head and accepted the pipe. [?] his face and Joined the dance   At the sacred lodge they offered him a cup of liquer made from the choisest medicines. all at once a propitiation and an initiatory rite.   This he drank at a single draught. and found his melancholy depart.   They all commenced their songs and dance. accompanied by [?weird?] ceremonies.  Some shook the medicine bag at him others had skins of birds filled with smaller birds that would leap out of the throat of the bag.   Their efforts cured Manibijou and he ate danced sang and smoked the sacred pipe and this inaugurated the Mysteries of the Grand Medicine dance.   The [?malicious?]  Manitos now all united in their efforts to restore Chibiabos to life and they succeeded but he was forbidden to enter the Sacred lodge.  They gave him through a chink a burning coal and told him to go preside over the country of souls. and reign over the dead. and with the coal to kindle a fire to comfort his Uncles and Aunts. which meant all men and women. and make them [?].  This was to be an everlasting fire."

197
"Maniiboju Catching Ducks."

   One time while Manibojou was living quietly alone. he felt very hungry.   There were plenty of ducks of all kinds on the lake near by but he did not know how to get them   At last he hit upon a plan. so he went to the woods and got a lot of [?Bannerd?] bark a whole sack full. and cumming to the Lake. where the ducks were he commenced to walk on the beach or shore singing to himself.  When the ducks saw that they were very anxious to know what their brother was about and calling to him asked him.  But Manibojou appeared to be very much interested and did not hear them. they continued to call and at last he pretended to be very much troubled. and answered them in an angry voice. and told them that they were annoying him ver much and at last told them he was going to have a dance and so they all agreed to go with their elder brother "Manibojou" and have a good time  So they went and built a large wigwam.  and Manibojou commenced to sing the ducks commenced to dance.  Manibojou advised them to dance with their eyes closed.   then he commenced to kill some.  but when he would choke one they would squak or quack. so that they should not know what he was doing.  at last one of the little ducks. known as the "Hell diver".. opens his eyes when he saw Manibojou in the act of breaking his brother ducks neck. and he commenced to holla and tell that Manibojou was killing them.  then the ducks began to fly away. and Manibojou Jumped in among them kicking and killing what he could. before they got away Maniboujou became very angry because of the action of one of his younger brothers - "he was the oldest of creation' - for telling on him so while Manibojou was kicking them out "in the hopes of killing more" he kicked the helldiver. on the back which left a mark for his curse., and that species of duck has a white spot on the back where Maniboujou kicked him when he [?] him out of the wigwam and he also gave this duck the red eye lid which they have to this day.  in a punishment for looking at him while he was killing the others.

198
Manibojou's Sentinal
On one occasion Manibojou had caught six ducks by an artifice. and he went and built a large fire to roast his ducks by burying the bodies and leaving the feet out of the ground.  When he got every thing fixed he was very tired. and resolved that he would go to sleep so he lay himself down in a position so that his face, elbows hand, knees and toes touched the ground - while the [?bent?] portion of his back was highest and pointed toward the lake. which he sat to [?watch?] while he slept for he was afraid some one might plunder him of his ducks.  Just as he expected, while he was asleep some indians were going along in a canoe close to the shore and soon they saw Manibojou and they knew at once that Maniboujou had something. for said one of the party. look at Manibojou he [?] [?] something let me go. so they went toward shore.  Just then they noticed Manibojou's sentinals and they raised a red flag. to tempt the sentinal not to say anything which the sentinal obeyed.   When the indians came to the fire, they tarred Manibojous watchman with pitch and  gum.  they they broke off the legs of ducks and took out the carcasses and stuck the legs back in the ground in their former place. as though they were unmolested. and left after a while Manibojou awoke.  Ugh! said he the ducks must have been cooked a while ago.  Mad because he thought that he over slept he pulled at the legs which yielded easily. then he tasted them he said they were well cooked and he began to dig for the carcases but to his dismay and indignation could not find them. and acusing [sic] his sentinal at once for alowing the thief to steal them. he said that he would punish him. so he began to carry a large quantity of wood which he lighted with the fire then turning his back to the fire he said he would fix his brother for disobeying.  So the hotter the fire grew the more he burned his back and legs till his flesh became crisp and [?] and making a noise like any hot or greesey wood.  He said I will learn you to say scinge.  "Scinge! imitating the noise of his burning flesh. thus he punished his disobedient sentinal.

199
[?] Law
The Ojibway Origin of Kinnikinnaile.

  On one occasion when Manibojou to punish his Sentinal on back for disobedience. roasted it till it was crisp over a fire he then. paying no attention to the suffering for his mind was full of the satisfaction of having thoroughly punished his younger brother he started out and any clump of bushes he walked over and brushed himself against he would leave them all red. with blood from his burnt back. this he turned into the red bush from which the indian [?] the great indian tobacco called "Kinicki nic". this said he will my grand father use to smoke. and to this day the tebacco is greatly coveted by the indians. because it was given to them by Manibojou.

Ojibway Story of the Origin of [?] Moss or "Trip do Rocho"
With his back blistered and burned by the punishment inflicted upon his younger brother his sentinal. Manibojou went to a ledge of rocks on the Mountain side and sat down. and slid along the rocks to cool his back. and as he did so the rocks would tear off portions of his burnt flesh. and when he made an ascent he would find the patches which he converted into the moss that the indian now eats. which he finds on the rocks.  Manibojou said "it should be used for food by his [?Grand?] fathers." which it is to this day.

200
"Manibojou Fishing"

  Once there lived two families in an unknown part of the world one was the family of "Manibojou" the other was the family of "Ma Ji ki ims."  they were very poor in worldly goods living entirely on a shrub called "Aginig".  One day as "Ma Ji ki. ims" was on his daily Journey digging. Aginig in winter he observed a very beautiful arrow fall very near him with the ear of a bear and also of Moose fastened on the head of it.   The arrow was very beautiful and majikims was afraid to take it. but a voice called to him from above saying majikimis take the arrow and contents then go across the lake on yonder [?] and light a fire and he did so then took off his foot wear to to dry the muccesins when the voice said your foot wear is very light and cold take these said the voice. and the fat sides of a bear and of a moose. these are my foot wraps said the voice.  MaJikiims took up the [?] and ate them all.  the voice told him to go. to the creek a short distance away and catch some small fish.  He would see them and put them in the Bare reed [?] sack that he would find there and go home..  And said the voice as soon as you leave the point you will hear threatening voices but I bid you not to look back. you must not go straight homeward but must take a by way and when you turn to your hut you will see a hollow on your right where you must cast your sack of fish be sure and not look back.  In the morning you can come and get your fish in the hollow.  He did as he was told. and as soon as he left the point he heard many voices calling to him. and some saying.  Ho!  Ho! that is MaJikimis kill him catch him take his fish away from im. and all sorts of threats. and the harder he ran. the closer the voices were cumming. he could not see who it was. for he was forbidden to look back.  When he reached the turning point and the hollow cast his load and ran home.   The next morning when "Majikimis" went where he cast his fish the night before he found to his surprise hundreds of different kinds of fish there which he took home to his wigwam and family.   About this time. his

201
friend Manibojou was getting low in his stack of "Agising" and had to go and look for more.   Being Jealous of his neighbor he watched him very closely and noticed everything MaJikimis would fetch to eat and when he saw his friend having so much fish he became very angry and went to visit him.  MaJikimis" he said where did you get so much fish.  Ha! said "Majikimis" I caught them very easy all I had to do was to get a long line of Bars [?] bark and go under the ice and string on all I found. and pull them out.  Ah! said Manibojou I will catch some in the morning.   When Manibojou left Majikimis went out and cut a large hole in the ice then anchored a large cat fish near by.  "Manibojou was on hand in the morning with a large string of  Bars [?] bark and dove in the hole through the ice that "Majikimis" had cut.  he thought he was very lucky when he strung on the cat fish that MaJikimis had anchored there the day before, but soon getting disquieted and out of breath pulled on his string as a signal to be pulled up and was so disgusted when he got out that he started to look for new 'Agnig'   When he reached the spot where he usually picked his supply, he also saw an arrow fall from above quite near to him, it was a nice shining arrow. with the ear of a bear, and of a moose.   When Manibojou saw the arrow he started for it "Te [?wabic?]"! he said there is my arrow! No!  No! said a voice from above.  Manibojou that is not your arrow.  your arrow would not be so nice as that!  Maniboujou picked up the arrow and looked at it:  Yes! he said that is my arrow.  'Where did yoou come from said Manibojou talking to the arrow.   No Manibojou that is not your arrow but take it: said the voice. and go to yonder point and make a fire. . Go yourself said "Manibojou" MaJikimis did not say that said the voice which was that of some Great Manito.  When Manibojou heard MaJikimis name mentioned he suspected some trick. and went over and built a nice large fire. took off his Meccesins and warmed his feet.   When the Manito dripped the fat sides of a Bear, and of a Moose, these said the Manito are my foot wear.   Manibojou reached for the meat "ho ho." he said these are my [?nips?]. these are the ones   No said the Manito.  your nips would not be so good as these.  Manibojou greedily ate all of the fat sides, and when he finished the Manito told him to go to the

202
creek catch some fish. he would find there.  Go and catch them your self said Manibojou.  Why Manibojou MaJikimis did not say that!  Manibojou again getting suspicious went and caught some fish at the creek of which there was plenty.  Now Manibojou said the voice of the Manito.  when you leave the point go in a round about way. and you will hear voices calling to you but you must not look back.  When you turn. you will see a hollow:  throw your load there and do not look back.  "Oh ho"! said Manibojou do you suppose that I am going to throw my fish away after carrying them.  Yes!  you can get them in the morning.  You want to get them yourself. said Manibojou.  MaJikimis did not say that said the voice.  Again Manibojou grunted and said that he would do so.  As soon as he left the point. he heard.voices calling to him and threatening to kill him.  that made Manibojou run.very hard and the harder he ran the reason the voices were [?] and they said take his fish from him.  he could stand it no longer but instantly turned Onaha!  Onaha! X he said and kept on running. and up to this day in the winter when the wind blows the snow in the air. the indians say. that was caused by Manibojou looking back.   When he reached the turn he cast his load of fish in the hollow - and in the morning he went down but to  his dismay found nothing. 
"Onaha", is an Ojibway expression of surprise.

203
"Manibojou The Great Indian World [?Maker?]"
Manibojou disgusted at his ill luck at fishing started out all by himself.  left his family behind and travelled he cared not where.  He left his friend "MaJikimis" after travelling for a while he became very hungry as he had nothing with him but his bow and arrows.  After a while he heard a noise in the bush "Te wah netchin" + he said come out I want to speak to you:  Ah.  Manibojou!  what are you doing here? said a large Moose. comming out of the brush:  You are Just what I want said Manibojou and drawing his arrow to the head shot the Moose. then he went to work and cooked some for his meal and saved the oil and put it in some birch bark dishes.   While he was eating, he heard a tree creaking with the wind.  "Te nah netchin." said Manibojou what is the matter with you up the"Lo nah!  my brothers. said he do not look near re and went on eating, but as soon as he commenced to eat the noise would again sound.  "Lo nak," he said you are a lot of trouble to me. so he started to go and see what was making the noise.  he climbed the tree and Just then the wind wrenched the tree and opened the crack and Manibojou put his hand in it to see what was [?].  Just at that moment the wind ceased and Manibojou was caught.  "Te wah netchin" said he let me go.  what are you doing?  Just then a pack of wolves were going by.   Just where Manibojou was having his feast.   This must be Manibojou's work said the wolves let us eat.   When they got through Manibojou was very angry.  "Lo wah! my brothers said he do not look near the trees..  Hahlo! said one of the wolves hear what he says do not look near the trees he must have something there so they looked and found Manibojou's dishes of tallow.  all of which they soon ate. and went on  Just then a gust of wind came up and wrenched the tree open and let Manibojou out.  he descended very mad!  Te wah!  the fools they ate all of my meat. and as then was none left for him he picked up his bow and arrows and started onward.  Walking. along he came up with three wolves..one old one and two young ones.  Manibojou adopted the young ones as his nephews and the old one as his brother and walked along.  after a while it was determned that the two young ones should hunt.  (Of course Manibojou had transformed himself into a wolf.).  the youngsters had good success. but to the disgust of Manibojou they ate all they killed. as they went along and all Manibojou and his adopted brother 

+ "Te wah netchin" is an Ojibway expression of [?] the "Te wah" is analogous to Hello! and 'Netchin is used to express a [?] or {?}.  The idiom means "Hello my younger brother"  Manibojou being always old

204

could see was the bloody signs of the hunt.  they at last concluded to rest.   Then Manibojou's brother said that they had better camp for the night.  All they did was to all walk in a circle X  then a larger hut was made.   They lived there for a great while as the [?] were having good success in hunting. and were getting abundance of game.  After a while Manibojou's brother and one of his nephews determined to leave. the camp.  They left one of the nephews to stay with Manibojou and they lived happily together. the young wolf killed lots of game each day.  Manibojou liked his nephew. very well. and always welcomed him home with hearty greeting.  One night the young wolf failed to come home Manibojou knew at once what had become of him. and that he was taken away by his former brother.  Manibojou felt very badly and went to look for him.   He came and then he saw a hole in the ice. and the tracks of his nephew. wolf and hunter where he was taken in the hole in the ice, Manibojou started out [4 unclear words] to get even with them for taking his hunter.  He [?] all winter till the spring when he came back with vengeance in his mind.   He went to the spot where he last saw the track of his nephew. and he caused the weather to be very warm. so hot. that the water was nearly boiling.   His scheme was to have all the animals come out of the water. and [?] themselves so that he might kill his offender.  He transformed himself into an old dry stick of a tree. and waited helding his bow and arrows behind him.  The animals began to come ashore in numbers and many different kinds. untill at last came his foe in the form of a large white wolf.   The wolf came to shade himself behind the only stick standing there. the old tree:  Manibojou. drawing his arrow to the head shot him twice and then ran for life. with many of the animals after him.   While Manibojou was walking through the woods musing over his success the day before. he heard some one crying. which startled him. and he went toward it.  He saw an old woman  cumming along with a large pack of Bass wood bark on her back  Hey! "Nokomis" (Grand Mother) where did you come from.  I went after some Bass wood bark! Well! what are you crying about?  then the old woman told him that their chief was at the point of death.  that Manibojou shot him the day before. and two of his arrows were stuck in his body. and that she did not expect to see him alive when she got back.  Manibojou then asked her 

X  The Ojibway to disignate a lodge or wigwam drew a circle.  so in this account the [?] made a circle which was equivalent to a home or camp.

205
which she was going to do with the Bass wood bark?  she said that they were going to run it from tree to tree so that if Manibojou came again, he would [?] against the string and no will knew it. and will drown him by flooding the country.   This explanation made Manibojou laugh!  Why said he. Manibojou must be a very wicked man I believe I will go and see your chief may be I can help him.  The old woman was very glad.   Manibojou told her to go ahead that he would follow.  When the old woman started Manibojou took a club and killed her then he went to work and skinned her from head to foot. he then donned the pelt and started for the camp of the sick wolf a very grief stricken old lady.  he was crying so loud that when he reached the hut he could not see his way and had to be led. to the sick king.   The old woman then put down her load of Bass wood bark, and inquired how the chief was getting along.  He was told that he was nearly dying!  I guess I will try and do some thing. said the supposed old woman.  He looked up and then he saw in a corner his long lost nephew wagging his tail at him.   The young wolf knew him at once, and Manibojou too great care not to take any notice of him for fear. of being detected.   Manibojou commenced his [?] to suck blood. and during the performance he bit one of the arms and Just chopped the [?] of the chief and killed him.  With one bound Manibojou cleared the door and there the old woman's pelt fell from his body they knew at once it was Manibojou. and they commenced the flood.   The harder Manibojou ran. the nearer the water was comming, he knew what was going to happen. but it was beyond his power to surpress it he ran on until he come to a wood chuck digging his hole in the ground.  La.Nitchin! (Ha [?] Junior) what are you doing?   I am making my house!   I will live with you my Junior. said Manibojou.  Hurry up and dig your  hole.  I guess Manibojou you had better go out of here said our friend the wood chuck.  Well said Manibojou you smell to strong any how to live with. and getting out of the hole he ran as fasst as possible till at last he water over took him.   He climbed a high hill. then on to the tallest. tree. and the water kept on comming up till it reached his [?] and lower lip.  He thought he was lost where ever he looked he could see nothing but water.   I guess I am lost said he to himself. but Just then the water ceased to rise and seeing an otter swimming near him he called to him to come. and he told him

206
to come and dive under the water and get some sand. or ground. the otter dove but did not again appear. on the surface alive but shortly after Manibojou saw him come up dead he reached for him and restored  him to life after trying a few other animals without success he observed a musk rat swimming about.  Manibojou called to him to come and try the rat went down and after a long delay came on the surface dead.  Manibojou reached for him and examined the paws.  to his great joy he found some sand on them. and he restored the rat to life. . Then he held the sand to the sun till it dried. he then cast it in [?] and made a beautiful island he then went ashore and casted some more sand till his island was the world.   There Manibojou after the flood made the present world.. and he called all the animals to him and told them what they would be for. what benefit. they would be to the indians and he also [?] them. after this he retired. and now sits at half way between the two ends of the world. and every time the indian tells of him he hears it and smiles to himself and says. what foolish things must have happened now."

  This story comes to the writer first hand from the Ojibway of Lac du Flambeau. and it is the same in substance as  has been heard by other writers and proves it  Many have been led to t he assumption that the indians are of the "Lost Ten Tribes." and that this Legend shows that they knew of the "Deluge." but this simgle instance proves nothing.. the old time indians. had heard the story of the Deluge from the Jesuits who visited them early. and being in it self a startling narrative they have handed it down and added to it and fixed it up in indian fashion with additions and adjuncts. so that now it has again gotten back to the white man's ears. he at once Jumps at the conclusion that the indian knew it all the time and that he is a true son of Isriel. because he remembers as far back as the Deluge.  we think that this story is the christian account dressed up by the indian story teller.

207
The Man in the Moon.  ("An Ojibway Legend.)
Once there lived a family consisting of a man and wife and they were often tracked by a man cumming at night into their wigwam with a long pipe which he made the indian smoke of and then he would die and the sister would take his [?leads?].  This caused the squaw great grief as she would have to lay the body of her husband out side of the wigwam for a while where he would return to life. still it caused her much grief as this was very often repeated. so on one occasion of the killing she left the cabin. resolved to leave forever and wander away so having left she started. and whither she went she did not know. but kept on..  In the mean time the husband having returned to life. and seeing that his squaw had left started in pursuit and after a while came in sight of her. but found it impossible to get  only a certain distance. but not to approach her.  She kept on. and finally he found that he could not walk farther. but the woman kept going in the direction of the moon till at last she did arrive there where the moon sets with her bundles in her hand."

208
Pi Ute Giant  "A Dakota Tale
On the ReservationDakotas in Nevada is the effige of a man in adobe sixteen feet in length.  The Indian tradition runs to the effect that three hundred years ago an enormous indian came down from the North to kill the Pi Utes.  That he did kill many of them when the remainder rallied and commenced shooting the enemy.. as  he retreated they followed and finally killed him.  His remains lie buried under the clay man..  As the giant started to retreat he made strides sixteen feet long. and the further he went the steps grew shorter and shorter till he fell...Since the fall of the Giant.  The Pi Ute indians to the present time meet at the grave of the giant every year and clear the foot prints for one half mile round made by the giant. after which they heap this curse on his grave.

209
Fire Warning. or the Indian passing in Fire  ("An Ojibway Legend)
"Anish - in a be" (indian) Bi-ma-sa-bo-nad. (passing in fire)  The Bad Spirit gives to certain old indians the power to make charms that will kill any indian he may desire and then "Bad Indians" are at times transported by the Bad Spirit. through the air, in the shape of a Bear. and at night he is accompanied by fire.,"  A native told the writer that as he was     [?crossing?] Lac du Flambeau at night on the ice it got quite late and was a pitch dark night. when suddenly he heard the most  unearthly sounds and saw a great light. he turned and saw coming through the air the shape of a bear. illuminated with fire. he crouched down and the bear passed over him and he saw him disappear over the hill..   This the man said was true.   Then old men who have communication with the Bad Spirit will sometimes kill some one to get his heart to make medicine..  Their medicines are kept in a bear skin stuffed down in the legs. and paws. and the skin is kept by the old man and handed down from generation to generation.   This bad medicine bag is kept by the "Bad Medicine [?]"   as he is called.) out of sight and it is only by accident that it may be seen.   The legend is related of a child having been buried. at the village of Lac du Flambeau and at mid night this light was seen.  rushing. through the air toward the grave yard. and next morning the corps of the child was found laid on top of the grass with the heart gone

  On another occasion in the early part of the century a band of Ojibway from Lac du Flambeau were travelling to LaCrosse to get their Annuity  In this land was an old couple and an only son.  and as they Journied one night the old man died. and they buried him the next day. and Journied on.   When they had camped for the night the mother of the son told the young man to go back along the trail; but not in it. to the spot where they had camped the night the old man died and hide himself where they had buried the old man. and watch and he did so:  About mid night he heard first the cry of a wolf then the cry of a foxer and all manner of animals. and of birds and finally with the flash of light came the howl and presence of a hugh [sic] bear. which Jumped on the grave and commenced digging for the body.   The young indian with his arrow shot the bear and behold it proved to be the old "Bad Medicine Man" who had been Journeying with the company and the young indian had killed him."  When their "Bad Medicine Man"  was in need of a portion of the heart of a corpse for a [?] Charm or other purpose will not hesitate to kill an indian to procure it.   They usually victimize an old person or a child.

210
Ojibway. Brave Stories.  Ducks & Otters.
Brave Stories as hey are now recounted on the thread bare and ragged vestages [sic] of the exploits of valor and prowess narrated by the ancient brave of the Algonquin race as he stripped of his clothes and smeared with paint for the war. struck the war path with his tomahawk and told of the deeds he was going to accomplish or had so done.  Most generally it was the scalps he was going to take.   At this period the brave takes no scalps and contents himself with such stories as the following.  One hero left his place in the ring during the singing of the song for the "Braves". and said that "he had been very brave he was once wandering in the forrest a long way from his wigwam and he found the dead body of an indian that belonged to his village and he picked him up and carried him over his shoulder to the village."

   Another man said he was very brave.  he went hunting one day with only a single load of shot in his gun. he came to a lake. and saw a flock of ducks and as they arose to fly he brought his gun round in a circle with a quick Jerk and that scattered the shot and killed every duck.  On another occasion. he came to a lake and saw a lot of Otters sitting on their hind legs about a hole. in the ice watching for fish. and only having one load in his gun he put the barrel between two trees and bent it round. and so fired and killed all the otters. at once."

211
"How the Indians get to like whiskey"  ('An Ojibway Legend')
One day a squaw went to gather wood and she saw a white man [?] something against a tree and the drips flew out in all directions and she was frightened and hid. and went to her tribe and told them what she had seen.   The next day the indians with their bows and arrows crept up to surround and capture the white man. and as they crept round they finally discovered that they in turn were surrounded and they found that the bright sticks the white men had were guns and that they were captured by the white men. who tried to make friends of the indians and they set food before them but the indians would not eat. as they told each other that the white men would kill the indian with poison and after several days they gave the indians an ox. and. they would eat as it was killed by themselves..  Then they gave them salt and one of the indians more venturesome than the rest. ventured to taste it. but it did not please him and he spit it out. finally the white men offered him whiskey. and the other indians tried to keep him from drinking it but he said if it killed him all right. and he took a drink and it was so good. he took another. and then he began to rave and talk and the indians got afraid of him. and then he drank some more and got dead drunk and the indians thought he was dead and they were about to bury him. when he came to and told them all how good it was and they all then tried it and they were pleased and made friends with the white men.
Heaven (An Ojibway Legend.)
Once an indian died and after a time he was sent back to the earth. to tell the indians not to accept the white mens religions as there was not the same heaven for them both. that in one room of heaven were the indians that had Joined the Roman Catholic church. and in an other the others. and those that were Catholics were as he said on the bank of a river digging roots. to live on. because they had not [?]. and the Manito made them work and they were arranged in rows one above the other. and there was a drum there but no one was drumming yet the drums was making a great noise.  And the catholic indians had their nails all worn off from digging roots.  For this reason the Indian will not accept the white man's religion as it makes them work to hard after death."

212
Cyclone
The Ojibway Indians. believe that a cyclone is the Manito or Spirit who transforms himself into the shape of a large bird. and as he sometimes flies low the way must be cleared for him and in consequence of the narrowness of the cyclone a heavy wind goes ahead of the Manito to clear the way.  the manito in the cyclone is invisible"
Thunder 
Wasininibi - {Bright Elm" an Ojibway at Lac du Flambeau and an old man give it as the origin of Thunder that it is caused by birds and in proof of this he stated "than one day while out hunting he came up to a small lake where there were ducks and having shot at them without killing any the birds arose and circling round rose higher & higher until they were out of sight. when he observed a small cloud appearing in the sky. then he heard thunder comming from the same distance. and after three (3) successive peals of thunder he saw the birds appear again from the skies and again alight on the lake. but he would not then shoot at them as he supposed it to be a warning from the Great Spirit of some importance."  Other Ojibway indians say that the thunder is caused by swallows. and animals of the earth.

213
"The Origin of the Big Ojibway Drums"
"Some twenty or thirty years ago. among the Dakota tribe of indians an out break arose and on one occassion. of a battle between the United States troops and a band of Dakota Indians. the whole band engaged in this encounter were killed by the troops save one native woman. who saved  herself by wading in the water of a lake and placing a water lillie leaf on her head. which shielded her from the observation of the soldiers.  She remained for four successive days and nights without food.   The cause of her remaining so long in the water was the camp of the soldiers at this spot on the bank of the lake.  On the morning of the fifth day she heard a voice calling to her. in her native tongue and being alarmed she dove out of sight for a moment but on again appearing she observed an old man on the shore with gray flowing beard who told her not to be afraid, but bade her come ashore. which she did.   The old man asked her if she was hungry and she replied she was.  Then he [?] he go to the soldier's camp and have her breakfast and said she must not be alarmed as he would cause her to be invisible so that the soldiers could no see or harm her.  After partaking of her meal the old man again called to her to follow him and bring along with her the wash tub. that she observed. lying in her pathway.  On arriving a short distance from the encampment they halted.   There the old man told her he was the Great Spirit. and that he saw and knew that she was in the water during the four days she was hiding but he could not come to her assistance as he was planning and regulating a religion which he would then relate to her.   Presenting her with a short stick he bade her strike the tub which she did and immediately the tub was transformed into a most beautiful  drum.  (From this circumstance the Ojibway make all their Big Drums out of birch tubs or in lieu thereof a half barrel) and to this day. a tribe cannot make a new drum unless they have authority from this woman

214
who is still young and alive for the Manito ordered it so. and they must have a piece of the original drum. or of a drum that has had a piece descended from the original drum.  When she deigns to give her consent she plucks a bead or some other trinket from the original drum and sends it to the tribe. which wants to make a drum.

  After this the Manito. pointing to a distance. showed her where the remainder of her tribe were. and told her to take the drum. to her tribe and he would guide her safely home. and advise them to Join and dance. and that the next time the soldiers undertook to drive them (as the Manito said it was to bad. the way the natives of the soil were treated) all the tribes should [?] and dance and not pay heed to the soldiers.. It is said that they did Just as they were bidden and when the soldiers came upon them they saw the indians having a good time and did not molest them.   That gave the indians an opportunity and the indians say that they watched their chance and killed the soldiers to a man:  It is this dance that has caused peace between the Dakota & Ojibway indians as before this they were bitter enemies.  The first feature of this dance is to raise a flag on a pole..  This is a request to the Manito for a clear day as the Manito told the woman that he always stood on the flag pole to look on. and before he is ready to retire he gives notice so that the indians can sing four or eight songs as he is going back."

215
Ojibway (Pottawatomie) Theology   X
The Ojibway natives believe in two Great spirits One. "Kitchemenedo" or the Great Spirit and "Matchemenedo" the evil spirit.  They revere the "Kitchemenedo" because he gives them all good things. and will not harm them but they fear "Matchemenedo" and make every effort to propitiate him and not anger him least he should send them harm or take their lives.
Ojibway Account of the Origin of the Indian.
"Kitchemenedo" displeased at the first creation of [?] threw the world into a great lake. and made one man whom he placed upon the earth.   The man was very lonely so "Kitchemenedo" sent a sister to cheer him.  One day the man told his sister that at night five yung men would come to her lodge as suitors. to select her.  But that the Great spirit forbade her to look, or smile at the four that should come first but when the fifth came she should speak to him smile upon him and rise and recieve him.  Thus instructed she waited.   The first suitor was called "Usama" (Tobacco) and he being rejected fell down and died.   The second man "Wapako" - "pumpkin") next "Eshkassinmin (the melon) and after him "Kokees" = (The beans) all these shared the fate of the "Usama" they were refused and died.  At last came "Tamin" or Mentamin" (the maize) when he called she opened her door and was glad to welcome him.   They were married and from that union sprung the indian race.   The dead suitors were buried and from these grass grew.  The "Pumpkin", "melon", "Tobacco" & Beans" these the Great Spirit gave to the indian as food and to cheer him.

X For other Folk Lore Stories the work of H. R. Schoolcraft will furnish an ample store.

Dakota Head Dress
[Four Images]
Dakota (Sioux) Head dress:  (Adams Coll..Haupt del)
length                10 inches

All Indian tribes without exception we believe wear on occasions of ceremony as the dance as an ornament or decorations for the head.  This article of dress like all articles worn or used by the red man varies according to circumstances.   It would seem that given a certain center in the Dakotas or other nation we find that as the members of the nation stretch away from that center their accustomed articles of tribal dress are more or less influenced by the people near whom they live.   In the north the Dakota is more or less influenced by the Ojibway. and in the south by the Apache. of New Mexico..and by the Paunee of Arizona.  The Paunee in elders times used a roach of hair standing like a cocks comb on the tip of the head.  This was a natural quiff of hair.  But was the

217
Dakota. wear a roach that is fabricated from the hair of the Deer and Porcupine. ingeniously woven so that the hair shall stand erect when secured upon the head.   This specimen is made by weaving the hair of the deer or antelope about a cord and tying it. a bunch of hair is bent round the cord and tied by a thread of sinew or other material.  These strips of hair are then sewed together to form a roach or comb of an elongated shape round in front and tapering to the rear.  the length is usually ten inches although shorter ones are made there is no exact rule in point of size. nor is there any exactness regarding the dyes used for coloring. the hair. The hair of the porcupine being variegated seems to answer the purpose of an indian without any other coloring. but the deer hair is dyed. red purple or yellow as the case may be.   This specimen is made up of a single layer of yellow hair. then a single layer of porcupine hair. then follows a single layer of purple hair. and the rest is all red.  It may happen that the center will be all yellow or purple. To spread the hair side wise this specimen has a piece of bone taken from a scapula. placed on top and perforated with holes. through which pass thongs of buckskin to tie the head dress to the hair of the the wearer.

  This specimen was procured by Dr. John C. Adams after the rout    of "Big Head" a [?] indian engaged in the Pine Ridge out break. in  1890.
   The effect of such a head dress upon a head of raven black hair and a face painted [?] one half black and the other vermillion or green and [?] makes certainly a grotesque. if not a picturesque appearance.

When the hair of a Dakota has been braided to his satisfaction as relates to the long plaits that hang down the sides of the head it is usual to add a piece bead [?]  as an ornament. to the crown of the head. such strips are shown in the drawing. and is a tail of a buffalo calf the short hair of the animal is turned toward the head of the indian and the flesh side of the skin; [?] is ornamented with beads sewed to a strip of buckskin.  The field of the beads is light blue with rectangular parts of dark blue along the edge. are dark blue. red and green beads and at the upper corners are tassles of strips of buckskin. wrapped with porcupine quills dyed green purple and yellow. the green occupying the ends.  the purple edging the yellow which is at the center.  Tin cones carrying red feathers are secured to the ends of the tassles.  Below the patch of beads is a tassle or fringe of five strips of raw hide wrapped with porcupine quills. the outer ones green the three central strips green. purple and yellow.. The strips are separated by a dark blue bead. and at the end of each strip is a large black bead. the upper and lower edges of the fringe are finished with red feathers.  The tail is tied to the head by a strip

219
of buckskin.  This specimen is from the Lower Brules agency and not only a relic of the Dakota indian but of the buffalo as well.  There have been no buffalo in that region for many years.

  The other type of hair ornament is one composed of beads worked upon a strip of buckskin and backed with a strip of red blanket.   The tails have no backing.   The body of the beads is of a light blue color.  with peculiar [?] descript figure wrought in dark blue, yellow and red. the dark blue. is on the outside of the figure. the yellow next and red is the center on the tails. the body is yellow. with beads of dark green. and patches of red and pink with [?] of dark blue with a light blue center.   The lower inch and a half of the tail                      is a string of beads wound about the buckskin. which terminates in two naked tails.  This is a Dakota specimen that belonge to one of the prisoners of war captured with Sitting Bull aster the Carter massacre. and his retreat into Canada.

At the extreme end of the long braid of hair the Dakotas wear an ornament or tassle made of a small rounded body of beads made of different colors sewed to buckskin.  The variety of color is of course near the same the indian mind cannot grasp the idea of symmetry or the necessity for the repudiation of two things of the same kind.   These hair ornaments have for the ground a section of dark blue and a section of light blue beads with a line of white parting them. on the tip of the ball is a loop of pink beads and at the lower end is a [?]. of three strips of buckskin. wrapped with purple.and red. porcupine quills. and terminating in tin cones.   This one [?runs?] very largely and the pair is from The White River Camp at the Lower Brulé Agency. South Dakota.   The Ojibways as a rule finish off the hair with a strip of buckskin or a ribon [?] using beads

The Dakota Squaw is not like the men permitted to don the war bonnet and eagle plumes but she confines her self to the wearing of a head band this is a strip of buckskin of elongated strips very irregular in out line. but ornamented to suit the fancy of the squaw this she wears tied across her forehead   This head band is made of two pieces secured together and is ornamented with rectangular makings of beads   In the centre the beads are white with blue central blocks on either end this central [?] is marked off by a line of deep blue and yellow beads in parallel lines the yellow in the middle.  On the right and left are patches of green beads with red central blocks and a parting of blue & yellow are in the center   The ends are of green beads with a central block of white.   At the lower edge of the band are ten points of yellow porcupine quills and at the top and bottom of each of the blue and yellow lines of beads are strips of buckskin terminated with the tin cones and horsehair dyed yellow.   This head band was owned and worn by "Crow Kane" a squaw captured at Pine Ridge in 1890 while at war with the United States troops, and she said that he yellow horse hair the indians collected from the helmets of the cavelery troops killed at the Custer massacre in Montana.

    Hair ornaments are among the most common articles of apparel and even if the buck wears no clothing he still considers himself well dressed if he have an ornament in his hair   The styles and forms of this kind of decoration is very great and we can only at this time give the type  the common form is a circle or ring made of wood and covered with any convenient material.   The chief object is a shiney object that will attract attention but in the case of the Hair ornament worn by Standing Bear "Matonoji" a prisoner at Fort Sheridan Ills.  The [?] of the ornament seems to be its [?] [?]    It consists of a thin strip of wood 3/8 inches wide formed into a ring and bound with sinews to the circumference of this ring and twenty seven strands of buckskin tied and each seems to be tied to its neighbor one after the other till the center is reached here a [?] is made of fur strands and at the intersection two long thongs are left to secure it to the head.   This is all colored red. more or less brilliant.
  Some times the ring is covered with strands of braided porcupine quills of different colors as in the Davel necklace shown in this chapter.   This ornament seems to be peculiar to the Dakota stock.

The Ojibway squaw is an adept in the art of weaving beads.   The Dakota squaw will sew beads upon buckskin in a variety of forms stringing a number of beads of diverse color together and sewing them on the buckskin but they do not do any thing at weaving.   The frame or loom and the method of weaving we show in another place.   this illustration is that of a collar [?] in triangles of different colors as dark blue, red, green, yellow and orange. with a filling in of white   At the ends is a line of green beads and a finishing of red ribon and [?] the center is a double line of blue beads.  suspended to the lower margin is a fringe four and one half inches deep. made of all the colors mentioned with pink amber black turquois & garnet beds [?] in the most irregular pattern and variety of arrangement such as it impossible of description.  The fringe is not [?] a constant feature in the collar.  most of them are without it.  This collar was lined with a sheet of birch bark to give it rigidity.  this feature does not exist in the garter or the sash  It has it use also in preventing the moisture of the neck from rotting the thread.  In dancing the neck perspires and by use the thread is rotted if not protected. by the impervious bark.  This specimen was ?] by a son of Andrew [?Cadotta?] at Lac du Flambeaux Wisconsin

223
which is worn at the dance or other ceremonial.   The gentlemen of a decade or so back used the rigid "stock" which was tied about the neck.with bits of [?tape?] and in the same way the Dakota indian. ties about his throat in the dance a collar of Deer toes.  Such a collar are not a common occurance however.  this one is owned by Rev. W. A. Sherman and is the only one the writer has seen. although there must be more because if one indian sees another with something he has not got. he must have it. if he can.

  The squaws seldom either among the Dakota or Ojibway. wear collars she does not participate in the dance or in ceremonials of any kind. hence there is no occasion to deck herself out in such finery. all her time is occupied in making finery for her lord. and then if she have any time left she may add a few things to her own dress..

Another form of necklace worn by the Dakota is one made of the pits of the wild small red plums.  This fruit is used as food and the pits preserved and after being dyed of different colors and drilled at one end with a hole are sed as a substitute for beads. and furnish good material for a necklace.   This necklace is made of four hundred and nine such plum pits secured to a strap. (The drawing does not shew so many because the [?] necessary to get them all in would confuse the picture to an [?] degree.)  The manner of securing them is to perforate the thong of leather at two places and pass through the hides the ends of a short piece of buckskin thong (the size is shown in the enlarged sketch) and to the ends to tie a plum pit.  The strap in the specimen represented is Seventy inches long   The pits themselves are variously colored a majority are of the natural color assumed by a dried pit. a goodly number are dark green. and a few red.  It is a fact worthy of note we think that when the article of manufacture has a few colors. they are apt to be the complimentary colors as in this case the red and green are found. in others yellow and blue. although the rule is not always observed especially if a number of colors are used when a rainbow perfusion may be expected.  This necklace was owned and worn by "Woonkapi cetangi"  "[?Soloman?]  Yellow Hawk" a Dakota from the Lower Brulé Agency.  Such a necklace was [?] as will be seen by referring to the picture of "Knife."  chapter II

Dakota (Sioux) Dance necklace.  Haupt Coll. & del.
length                 65½ inches

The most elaberate [sic] and curious necklace in our collection and we believe in the making of the Dakotas is that made of deer toes and bit of horn.  This specimen which was also the property of Woonkapi cetangi "[?Soloman?] Yellow Hawk" is a study the foundation (as it were) upon which it is built. is a strap of leather Sixty five and one half inches long and about half an inch wide. fastened at the ends. and perforated at irregular intervals with holes. through which pass short thongs in a manner similar to those used in the plum stone necklace.  In this specimen however instead of terminating with a plum pit at each end a bit of deer toe or nail. or a strip of horn cut in and and all kinds of fashion and dyed black green or red as the case may be is tied   There are on this necklace one hundred and forty eight such bits of toe or horn and no two of them are alike (and again we have not attempted to draw them all to prevent confusion).   At intervals along the strap a single thong of buckskin is inserted and a knot made in one end leaving a long loose end.  to the other end of the thong is secured a brass thimble. stuffed with an assortment of articles in one a bunch of downy feathers. in another strips of buckskin. one contains the tail of a Prairie dog. and a fourth a bunch of blue & red calico rags. each different and there are in all. thirteen in all

227
The end ones [3 unclear words] the other the tail of a fawn of the Black tail deer.  At the place where the straps are [?] is tied the skin of a deer foot with the toes and hoofs remaining on the skin. this is dressed or tanned and colered [sic] red on the flesh side. the hoofs are cut with hoes, filled with red paint.   To the end of the necklace is secured on a tassel the tail of a white tail deer dyed blue. and at the rest of the tail is a small pinch of calico containing some dance medicine: (The nature of which is not revealed) and a tiny sleigh bell.  At the extreme end is a ring two and five eights [sic] inches in diameter made of wood and wrapped with strands of braided porcupine quills.   In this case red and white. the cross in the centre to which is tied a (once) blue ribon is of [?] of sinew. which with the addition of the humeri of the Prairie dog to the number of two completes the description.   Necklaces of this kind are extremely rare and from the time consumed in making them should as the white man figures it comes high. but time to an indian cut no figure.  If the indian was as sensative [sic] as the ordinary white man. and more especially white women such a yoke about their bare neck and shoulders would we should think make them dance in the absence of the soul stirring tom tom..  This necklace admirably fills the requirements of the indian for it has the necessary Jingle and when shaken sounds like the ringing and Jingling of sleigh bells..

228
Necklace of Spotted Tail
[Image]
Dakota (Sioux) Bear's Claw Necklace.  owned by "Spotted Tail."  Wyman Coll. (Haupt del)
length 16½ inches

The old time indian is the good old days wore articles of adornment made from trophies of the chase. or war. but now their degenerate descendants condescend to wear the cheapest and most gaudy cheap Jewelry of the white man.  "Spotted tail" however belonged to the old regime and with others of his race wore articles of dress that had a history.  This necklace is one made of eleven claws of the grizzly bear "Ursus horribilis." and there is little doubt but that the bear was killed by the chief himself it is not a common thing for an indian to wear [?] the fruit of some other man's hunt.  they consider it a mark of bravery to be [?] to procure such trophies. and are not prone to display the result of some other man's deeds.   The claw is removed with a part of the bone holding it and this is usually colored . in this specimen it is red. or was before it wore off and by drilling a hole in this bone the claws are strung. like beads.   The largest claw is four and three quarter long and the shorter three and one half inches in length.  the claws are worn in any different positions as the fancy of the indian dictates.  sometimes they are down as shown in the drawing at other times they are reversed and turned up to project outward.  This specimen we procured for purpose of illustration from the [?] Wyman. and are informed that the specimen had originally twelve claws and that the former owner being [?] to part with all of them retained the twelfth claw as a Souvenier.

229
Dakota Necklace bead
[Image}
Dakota (Sioux) Necklace bead.   (Haupt. Coll. v del.)
Actual size.
Beas are a necessary adjunct to the happiness and adornment of the indian. and in the absence of [?] obtained from the white man. which are sought as they possess more brilliancy of color any object almost which can be converted into a bead is used.   The wampum is a shell. and is very highly prized   the shell of the "Cowrie" is among the Ojibway a thing acred   . it is a [?Niciuto?] and in the roar of the sea which they hear in it. they recognize the voice of a Manito.   The bead in the drawing is one found by the writer on the summit of a "butte" east of Fort Totten N.Dakota at the grave of an indian whose body had been exhumed. and removed. but the ghouls dropped this bead. it is made from the thick portion of the shell of the fresh water clam. which abounds in the Northern waters.  It shows marks of having been made by drilling the center and rubbing [?] or the out side.  Such a bead most likely took the greater part of a day to make if not more than one.  and it is easy to imagine that the elaboration of such a necklace consumed months.  and such necklace was common only before the advent of the white man.  He brought with him beads ready formed and obtainable with a few. or it might be many pelts..but even then it cost less than to make them. and for this reason the construction of beads of shell and other material died out.  It seems to be an instinct of proclivity stamped upon the human that the costume is not complete without the necklace of beads. almost every human race secure beads of some kind or another.  From the most degraded of all savages up to the most brilliant among  our white sisters beads are universally worn. with the exception of the white man in the civilized countries.

The Dakota Medal-pouch is a rare bit of indian finery. in former days in treaty with the indians the agents of the Government were wont to give to the Chief with whom they met in [?] and especially so if the chief acquiesced in the wishes of the agent or government. a medal which the chief wore as an insignia of his chieftanship. a number of chiefs were so made who had no other title to chieftanship than that an agent, or it might be a trader had given him a medal.  When the English possessed the west next a good many medals bearing the face of the British Sovereign new now before

231
that many french and of later times not a few bearing the head of "Old Hickory"  "Andrew Jackson," are among the treasures of the Dakota. and other indians but lest they are rare. and Rev. Stobie the owner of this specimen is of opinion and there is no reason to doubt the correctness of his conclusion that this pouch was used for the purpose of carrying one of these medals and is made of buckskin.   Two disks of skin. the front one six inches in diameter the back one with the fringe nine and three quarters inches in diameter are sewed together with sinew. to form a pouch leaving at the upper edge an opening three inches long as a mouth.  At the mouth is a triangular piece of skin and from the ends of the triangle is a broad strap or band made of two parallel strips of buckskin with strips of raw hide sewed between and each wrapped with porcupine quills dyed red. and others left natural. with a narrow strip of bark between the red and white the strip is forty inches long and two and one half inches wide.   The front disk of he pouch is worked in quills two triangles one of red with an edge of a [?] [?fibre?] the bark of a tree. and a single row of [?] about the edge the rest is white   Below the disk are two strips of raw hide covered with quills.  the top one is red on the ends a parting of brown and a centre white the lower one is like it except that the ends are carmine instead of red.  About the edge of the pouch is a fringe of buckskin. made by cutting the edge of the rear disk into shreads.   At the bottom of the pouch is a fringe made of ten bits of raw hide sewed to edge of the rear disk and wrapped with porcupine quills below the quills as each such strip is a deer's toe. and below this a leaf of raw hide wrapped with carmine and white quills and with two narrow strips of buckskin at the sides of the fringe. the pouch is complete.  The workmanship is very odd and the effect gorgeous.  This specimen Rev. Stobie procured in the [blank space] country from.

The custom of painting the face and at times the entire body is a practice in vogue among all wild people. and there is the greatest nicety of distinction made by them as to the color used.   Among the Dakota. tribes and to a great measure the same is true of the Ojibway a definite color is an important factor in the success or failure of the ventures entered upon by the individual   at the time of his initiation into the mysteries of Medicine the Great Spirit reveals to every brave. his color. and for that reason certain colors are to the brave sacred. and he believe that when he wears that tint he is [?propitiating?] the spirit and that success will attend his efforts therefor..  the color a brave wears. also frequently give origin to his name.  The "yellow" in " [?Solemen?] Yellow Hawk," the name of a Dakota indicate that yellow was his mystic color..  So Red Turtle. the name of an Ojibway. indicates that he affected red as his color.  the belief in the efficacy of colr is so deeply implanted in the mind f the indian that he attributes any failure that may befall hm to the fact that he did not wear the proper color and the combinations of color which the indians do wear are startling.  Should the brave cover his body and face with black the indication is that

233
he is wearing mourning and he is intent upon killing [?same?] and to assuage the death of his relation or as they express it to "satisfy the spirit of the dead." and the manner is by custom prevented from wiping off the black till he has taken the blood of an enemy to appease the spirit of the dead:  By many it was not understood that the one killed must to the party who did the killing. for it frequently happened that the death was by disease. any person whom the avenger might meet was the enemy in that case.   The Ojibway have a ceremony in their "Big Dance." for wiping off the Black that will be described in the proper place.   They formerly resorted to the killing of their enemy to satisfy the spirit. and usually were [?] careful to visit retribution on the aggressor.  even if it took years to come in contact with him.   The more brilliant the color the better it was suited to the task of the indian.   In early days the red was the "Slime that comes up from the streams."   The deposit in other words of iron from [?iron?] springs was collected and heated and used as a red paint. it is the "red oxide of Iron."  The blue among the Dakota was the "blue earth." found in Southern Minnesota on the Blue [?]  River. in the county of the same name.  the banks are of a blue color this earth the Dakota used to paint themselves with.  The Ojibway use the rotten wood which is found in the forest.  The Phosphate of Iron in the decaying wood imparts to it a green and at times blue color. and this was used as a pigment.   Black is made on "The [?] [?]"  explained by "boiling the slime from a "Grind Stone" with oak leaves and branches."  litterally [sic] this is ink.  The yellow is the ochre they find in certain places   Of these aboriginal colors the only one now in use is the "black" this is still employed by the Ojibway. to color the reeds for the "Anakan"  "mat."  The more brilliant analine dyes of the white man are the colors resorted to by the indian.  These they carry so far as the Dakota or [?] in ornamented bags of powder.   The Ojibway wrap them in a rag and tack them away any where.  the first specimen of Dakota Paint bag is from the Lower Brulé Agency. in S. Dakota it is made of buckskin finely dressed. and ornamented with beads the ground is of yellow beads. with points and triangles of dark blue. in the middle of each triangle is a line of light blue beads.  The fringe at the bottom is of buckskin smeared with yellow pigment   The buckskin thong that ties the mouth shut is ornamented with a tassle of buckskin wrapped with porcupine quills dyed red. purple. and yellow. and finished with tin cones carrying red hair.   The second specimen is one made by "Little Eagle." a son of "White Eagle" one of the leaders in the "Custer Massacre."  This "Little Eagle" at the time he made this specimen was ten years of age.   It is from "Camp Poplar River," Montana. and obtained May  9th 1887.  The leg is long and narrow It came to me as a "paint bag" but from the style and proportions

2334
and judge it to be a toy or an immitation of the tobacco pouch. referring to the tobacco bag made by "Sitting Bull" Chapter IV. it will be seen that the ornament of the mouth of the bag is like that of the pouch. while the raw hide fringe and finish of the lower end is like that of the tobacco pouch shown with the pipe of " [?] " we call attention to these facts because that finish of the mouth of the tobacco pouch seems to be a local peculiarity.
The mouth of this Paint bag has four [?] continuous  with the bag. the [?] of each [?] has some of green and yellow beads and a finish of tin cones.   The body of the bag has a line of green blue and yellow. beads at the two sides. and a band of green across the bottom with a center of black blued. yellow and red.  The raw hide fringe consistes of nine strips     wrapped with red quills with a central figure of white with green marginal lines and a red center.  the terminal fringe is of buckskin strips

It is only a limited number of the Dakota (Sioux) indians who have acquired a taste for the white man's Jewelery. as articles of adornment. perhaps we err in saying they have not aquired a taste for it. it would be better to say they h ave not the opportunity to acqur it. therefore in lieu of it they make for themselves Jewelry from the things at hand.  Their articles are made of buckskin and beads. as a rule. [?] other things are employed as bits of horn cut in a fantastic shape..but then as [?].  The most common types are Turtles Lizzards Water bugs. and Bushes. these are made of buckskin and ornamented with beads.  Some times they are stuffed at others flat.   The turtle is a forest animal. and. the display of colors on the specimen of which we give a drawing is quite brilliant.  The body is of white beads..with a marginal line and points of dark blue. the feet and tail are strips of buckskin cut into a fringe at the end and each wrapped with red quills and terminating in tin cones. carrying purple feathers.   This is a Specimen from the Lower Brulé Agency.  The second is a "Water bug" or "Beetle" the body is pale yellow. with light blue ends and points. the legs. are strips of buckskin wrapped with purple and red. quills and having tin cones. carrying yellow hair.  the tail is four strips of buckskin wrapped with red quills.  This is a specimen from the Pine Ridge County in S. Dakota and belonged to a prisoner of war. captured at Wounded Knee in 1890.

From all time it would seem the encircling of the wrist with a band of some kind was a practice very common to all people and it would seem that it was a practice that marked the individual as of an intelectual development over the brute.   In history of man [?] we find a description of his life we find a description of the bracelet as a part of his adornment and the indians are not lacking in this peculiarity and we find the Dakota making for himself and her self a great variety of bracelets of beads. and about any other thing that may be [?].

 In the Dakota Armlet or Bracelet we have an illustration of a type. of article worn by the squaws of S. Dakota. at the White River Camp.  It is a band of three strips of raw hide.  Joined at the ends and held in the center. and sides by threads of sinew.  These bands are wound with porcupine quills. dyed. red. gree. and blue the red. predominate and the green. and blue are used to give relief to the color.  The place of union is marked by a tassle of four strips of buckskin wrapped with red porcupine quills and finished with tin cones and brass beads. which tinkle as the wearer moves.  We are often struck with the singular harmony of color which exists in the work of the Dakota indian and are at a loss to explain it.   They use as a rule the complementary colors and the [?] of color is as a rule larger than with the Ojibway yet there is far more conformity to principle and a better result.  Reds are usually associated with green. and yellows with blue. in such a manner that the result is quite brilliant and withal pleasing.  In this bracelet the red and green harmonize well. and the result is good.  The wearing of bracelets is not confined by any means to the Squaws.  The men and boys deck themselves off in such finery but of a different class than that of the squaws.  The bracelet worn by the men is usually of metal or a single strap with no tassle or other appendage.  As a type of the metal bracelet we show one taken

237
by the writer from the bones of a Dakota (Crow) indian scattered on the banks of the Yellowstone river in Montana.   This is simply a band of [?] iron which in life was hammered about the wrist of the wearer and from that day. till taken off his skeleton wrist it had been worn incessantly and had become quite smooth and polished.

A belt to a squaw is as indespensable [sic] as the pockets in the trousers of any white boy or man.. pockets are unknown in the fashion plates of the indians but that does not prevent the necessity of their carrying about with them a great variety of articles.  these are all hung to the dress.  those for ornament merely upon any conspicuous part while those for use usually to the belt.  The men are less fastideous [sic] as to the belt than are the women.  The squaw belt as here shown is a thing of splendor in the indian mind.   This is a strap of leather two inches wide which is studded all over in rows with brass headed nails.  The reason for the display in the squaw belt is that it is worn out side.  the belt of the man is as a rule covered by the shirt. and the indian while she will spend time to ornament an article that will show. does not spend much time on any article that is hidden.  In the chapter on "More [?] & children II we show the dress of a Dakota squaw with some of

239
sundry articles suspended from the belt. but in this drawing as we give the belt in detail we also add a detailed view of the "Awl cover". that accompanies the belt  This is a long [?] pouch of buckskin of a conical form and ornamented entirely with beads the color are green above and below with a central band of red. the red and green is divided by a band of blue and a central stripe of yellow.   The flap is beaded in the same colors but the [?dispention?] is different there are three bands of green and two of red. along. the edge. on [?] of light-blue and yellow beads.   The ends of both pouch and flap are finished with tassles trimmed in the case of the pouch and buckskin in the case of the flap.wrapped with bark dyed red. and quills dyed. green . and others left white. the end finished in tin cones and red feathers.  Within the case is an awl made of a piece of umbrella strut stuck into a willow handle.   Such awls have now altogether taken the place of the old fashioned bone awls. a few of these are new and then picked up in cover. or scraped out of springs when they have for years lain hidden but they are not made.  the steel awl being so much better.  The belt was formerly the property of "[?Lepij atociqi."?]  "[?] Small Forked Tail." at the White River Camp"  S. Dakota.

  The ojibway Squaw having adapted the dress of the white woman more or less modified the belt is not [?] by her to carry articles upon these are deposited in the pockets of the dress.

In chapter III we give a picture of "Knife" a Dakota who is fully arrayed for the dance in full dress including the Garters as here shown.  the pair [?] from which this sketch is made were not owned by "Knife" but "Angle" a Dakota from Cheyenne City.  South Dakota.   What kind of an angle this man might have made when he was admitted to the happy hunting ground is doubtful.   It is true that in the flesh he was very wide of the mark as to our imagination of celestial creatures however these garters are worn by the Dakota vey frequently and are ever present in the dance.  they are made of strips of raw hide wrapped with porcupine quills dyed. of various color. at the top the strips are secured to a narrow band. of cloth or buckskin about one eighth of an inch wide. the bottom of the strips are fastened together by strands of sinew or thread. with a tin cone carrying an orange colored feather. suspended to each.  The strips carry some four colors others only one   The outer edge. is read and yellow. then two strips all red followed by figure. the center of purple. with a band of orange. and green. about it and conforming in general and line with a filling of yellow surrounding them.   The next is a green rectangle with an orange centre    Then strips of red. and a second figure like the first and in the center a cross of yellow surrounded by red.  When on the leg the cross is in front and at the outer side hangs the tassle. which consists of four long strips of buckskin wrapped with red quills. with a [?] of purple. and the ends finished by tin cones bearing red feathers   Attached to the upper band at either end are thongs of buckskin with which it is tied to the leg.

224
Necklace
[Image]
The Dance Necklace (Dakota Sioux) is an article that the indian Dakota as well as Ojibway must have or his costume is not complete.  few white men's dress will stand the addition of a necklace though some wear gold chains as long. and certainly as heavy as the indians necklace but with an indian it is essential any thing that will go round the neck and hang gracefully from the shoulders answers the purpose.   A bit of strap studded with brass headed nails similar to that the squaw belt carrying the awl case will serve an excellent purpose as a necklace. but ordinarily when a Dakota "buck" is "gotten up." or is dressed or more properly undressed for the dance he wears a bead or other necklace a strap does not Jingle or make a noise and to the indian mind noise of a rhymithical [sic]  kind is the first element of a successful dance. and to that intent beads of the larger sort and other noise producing object are selected for the necklace.  The example is this cut is one made of about four hundred green and yellow beads strung in a double row upon strips of buckskin and the ends tied together with a couple of extra beads on the end of the thong    The colors of the beads are arranged in blocks a number of green beads alternating with a number of yellow but there is no limit to the number of the beads of the same color    This is the simplest form of necklace made. and is a good type of the ordinary bead article   This may be worn. and frequently is: with one or more. elaborate specimens indeed one time or more such necklaces may adorn the same individual.

The garter worn by the Ojibway is the dance was  illustrated in chapter IV under the head of bead work. and it only article left for us to describe now is the Dance Leggin of the Ojibway the Dakota. does not wear them. as an adornment for the dance. his use of the leggin is to protect the leg and when he dances. takes them off.  It seems to be incompatible with the notion of propriety for a Dakota to dance in any but a nude state.  The Ojibway on the other hand.   wears as he does the trousers of the white man add to his dance uniform if he has them the leggins.  the pair which is from the authors collection and were made at Lac du Flambeau Wisconsin. are a type of the Ojibway leggins.  The material is black velvet.  Just here let us remark in passing that velvet seems to be a favorite stuff for garments and other articles among the Ojibway. and we incline to the opinion that it is because the velvet has the texture and appearance in a great measure. of a fine fur. the Indian has a fine appreciation of fur. and is prone to use it when ever possible..  This leggin is a conical structure that fits over the calf of the leg. the outer edge is finished with an angular flap. which on the front side is ornamented with beads.  The Margin of the leggin is bound in orange & blue braid. and and the figures are wrought in red, white, blue green and yellow beads. we show one side of the leggin the other is similar the figure being carried out. with symetery. [sic]  This pair of leggins was owned by [?"Ojan-i-niwa wa. gi ji gon." ?]  "The Little Busy Day." and was worn by him. at the "Big Dance" witnessed by the writer. Oct 9th 1891. at Lac du Flambeau.
